metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of Hydrometeorological observation network (automatic weather station of Heihe remote sensing station, 2017)
metadata.description:
The data set contains meteorological element observation data of heihe remote sensing station in the middle reaches of heihe hydrometeorological observation network from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017.The station is located in the east of dangzhai town, zhangye city, gansu province.The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 100.4756e, 38.8270n and 1560m above sea level.The air temperature and humidity sensor is located at 1.5m, facing due north.The barometer is in the waterproof box;The tilting bucket rain gauge is installed at 0.7 m;The wind speed and direction sensor is located at 10m, facing due north;The installation height of the four-component radiometer is 1.5m, facing due south;The installation height of the two infrared thermometers is 1.5m, facing due south and the probe facing vertically downward.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm on the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm underground.The soil water probe was buried at 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm.Average soil temperature probes were buried in 2cm and 4cm;The soil heat flow plate (3 pieces) is buried 6cm underground.Two photosynthetically active radiometers were set up 1.5m above the canopy (one probe vertically upwards and one probe vertically downwards), facing due south.
Observation projects are: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1. 5 m, RH_1. 5 m) (unit: c, percentage), pressure (Press) (unit: hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_10m) (unit: m/s), wind (WD_10m) (unit: degrees), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:C), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (in watts/m2), soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_120cm, Ts_160cm) (in:C), soil moisture (Ms_0cm, Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_80cm, Ms_120cm, Ms_160cm) (unit: %), upward and downward photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_U_up, PAR_U_down) (unit: micromole/sq.s), mean soil temperature (TCAV) (unit: Celsius).
Processing and quality control of observed data :(1) ensure 144 pieces of data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2017-6-10:10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Liu et al. (2018), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Disjunctive.Question: Which technique is more commonly used for estimating evapotranspiration in oasis-desert ecosystems, the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model or the Shuttleworth and Wallace model?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection techniques used for measuring hydrometeorological variables in arid regions?
Where are the observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems typically collected?
What challenges are commonly faced in the data collection process for measuring surface fluxes in strongly advective environments?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Example.Answer: Field observations were made using a high-resolution thermal camera to measure soil and canopy component temperatures. These measurements were used as inputs to the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration. The data were gathered from a boundary layer tower and validated with eddy covariance system measurements and stable isotope techniques.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in the data collection process for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: One challenge is the crisis of ecological environment degradation, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification in arid and semiarid areas, which are critical for maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A dataset from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin in western China includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. This dataset is collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012.

Definition.Question: What is a typical data processing and quality control procedure for hydrometeorological datasets collected in oasis-desert systems?
Definition.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure for hydrometeorological datasets involves data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This includes observing radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period.

Definition.Question: How are soil and canopy component temperatures utilized in estimating evapotranspiration using a TSEB model?
Definition.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are used as inputs in the TSEB model to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration. These temperatures can be obtained from high-resolution thermal cameras and are crucial for partitioning ET into its soil and canopy components, thus improving the validation and accuracy of the model's estimates.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for hydrometeorological observations in the Heihe River Basin compare to those used in oasis–desert systems for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Comparison.Answer: In the Heihe River Basin, the hydrometeorological observations are conducted using automatic weather stations with sensors for air temperature, humidity, wind, radiation, and soil parameters. In oasis–desert systems, similar data collection involves eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, and weather stations for hydrometeorological variables, with an emphasis on long-term data collection since 2012.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when measuring evapotranspiration using a two-source energy balance model compared to maintaining ecological stability in oasis–desert regions?
Comparison.Answer: The two-source energy balance model faces challenges like the complexity of accurately estimating component temperatures and dealing with strong advective conditions. In contrast, maintaining ecological stability in oasis–desert regions involves addressing broader environmental issues such as land desertification, river drying, and natural vegetation degradation, which require long-term ecological and hydrological data monitoring.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring data quality and consistency in datasets involving multiple meteorological measurements over extended periods?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in ensuring data quality and consistency may include dealing with missing data points, instrument calibration errors, and environmental factors that affect sensor performance. The dataset's quality control process involves removing erroneous data, marking suspicious entries, and standardizing time formats to maintain consistency across extended observation periods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in measuring evapotranspiration accurately in arid regions using ground-based and remote-sensing observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in measuring evapotranspiration accurately in arid regions stem from the limitations of current composite temperature separation approaches, image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, and the strong advective environment that affects the energy balance closure with respect to available energy. Additionally, errors in estimating component temperatures and uncertainties in incoming radiation transmittances through the canopy contribute to inaccuracies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it essential to have long-term observations for understanding energy and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are essential for understanding energy and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems because they provide critical insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are necessary for maintaining ecological stability, supporting socioeconomic development, and achieving goals like carbon peaking and neutrality. They help recognize patterns and changes over time crucial for sustainable oasis development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainties in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures from thermal images in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures from thermal images in heterogeneous landscapes are primarily caused by image classification errors, where soil pixels are misclassified as vegetation pixels, leading to canopy temperature overestimation. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as uncertainties in the short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy, can contribute to these estimation errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using datasets from oasis–desert systems on understanding carbon exchange dynamics in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using datasets from oasis–desert systems can provide critical insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics in arid regions, which is essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This understanding is significant for protecting the ecological stability and supporting the socioeconomic development of oases, and it contributes to achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert ecosystems are to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial to recognize oasis–desert interactions, protect ecological stability, and support sustainable socioeconomic development. Understanding these exchanges is vital for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals in oasis–desert areas, ensuring ecological security, and promoting sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to apply the TSEB model using soil and canopy component temperatures derived from high-resolution thermal imaging in agricultural areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Applying the TSEB model using soil and canopy component temperatures derived from high-resolution thermal imaging is important because it allows for the accurate estimation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas. This approach provides robust estimates of latent fluxes for soil and vegetation components, which are validated against ground-based measurements, thus improving the accuracy of water resource management and the understanding of terrestrial water cycles.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations in the middle and lower reaches of river basins in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals of establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations in these regions include monitoring long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, and providing auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. This network aims to address ecological and environmental degradation challenges, support the ecological stability and sustainable socioeconomic development of oases, and contribute to understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can data quality control be effectively implemented when collecting meteorological and hydrological data from an automatic weather station?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality control can be implemented by ensuring consistent data collection intervals, such as every 10 minutes, marking missing data with specific identifiers like -6999, removing duplicate records, and eliminating data exceeding expected physical ranges. Additionally, questionable data can be highlighted, and consistent formatting of date and time is crucial.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be used to separate and accurately measure soil and canopy temperatures for use in evapotranspiration models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil and canopy temperatures can be separated and measured using high-resolution thermal cameras, which classify visible and near-infrared images into soil and canopy pixels. The maximum-likelihood method can be used for pixel classification, and the component temperatures are calculated by converting thermal infrared temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation and emissivities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in collecting and processing long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term data collection involves using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers to measure turbulent fluxes, with hydrometeorological data collected by automatic weather stations. Data processing includes organizing, processing, and quality controlling the data, which involves averaging over specific time intervals, ensuring consistency, and archiving for sharing. This process also includes supplementary data on vegetation and soil parameters.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the accurate collection and validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras to obtain soil and canopy component temperatures, along with the application of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, has enabled the accurate estimation and validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration data. The TSEB model's ability to use a single measurement of land surface temperature has improved its application across various vegetation types and climates.

Enablement.Question: How do ground-based measurement systems like the eddy covariance system and scintillometer contribute to the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Ground-based measurement systems such as the eddy covariance system and scintillometer provide half-hourly data on turbulent fluxes, which are essential for understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. These systems, combined with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data, enable a comprehensive analysis of ecological interactions and support sustainable development goals.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do data processing and quality control methods enhance the reliability of datasets collected from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing and quality control methods, including the removal of duplicate records, correction of physically implausible values, and thorough data archiving, enhance the reliability of datasets. These methods ensure the integrity of long-term observations, which are crucial for analyzing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems, thereby supporting ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Expectation.Question: Why is it crucial to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in data collection for sustainable development?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial because oases are unique ecological landscapes that are vital for the ecological environment and economic development, especially in arid regions like western China. Oases support a significant portion of the population and play a critical role in agricultural productivity. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these systems is essential for achieving carbon neutrality and ensuring ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Expectation.Question: Why might the TSEB model face limitations in arid regions when used for estimating evapotranspiration?
Expectation.Answer: The TSEB model may face limitations in arid regions because the current composite temperature separation approaches are not fully effective in these areas. Additionally, errors in deriving component temperatures can lead to inaccuracies in the model's performance. The strong advective environment and uncertainties in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures can also contribute to these limitations.
